This article provides insufficient context for those unfamiliar with the subject. Please help improve the article with a good introductory style. (June 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

The Student politics of Bangladesh encompasses the activities and culture among Bangladeshi students, mostly from the tertiary level of education, as part of the support they demonstrate for political parties at the national level.

Contents

  • 1 Major Student Organizations
    • 1.1 Bangladesh Chhatra League
    • 1.2 Bangladesh Jatiotabadi Chatra Dal
    • 1.3 Bangladesh Islami Chhatra Shibir
    • 1.4 Jatiya Chhatra Samaj
    • 1.5 Bangladesh Chhatra League (JASOD)
  • 2 Current Situation
  • 3 References

Current Situation[edit]

Student politics in Bangladesh is reactive, confrontational, and violent. Student organizations act as armaments of the political parties they are part of.[1] So every now and then there are affrays and commotions. [2] Over the years, political clashes and factional feuds in universities killed many, seriously interfering with academics.[3] To relieve tensions, universities often must resort to lengthy closures, resulting in truncated and overcrowded classes.

The student wings of ruling parties run campuses and residence halls through crime and violence. They control access to amenities in residence halls, favoring fellow party members and loyal pupils; eat for free from nearby restaurants, and help themselves to products from shops nearby; practice extortion; and take money from freshmen. Further, they put pressure on teachers for payment in exchange for supporting to school administration their hiring and retention.[4] [5]

References[edit]

  1. ^ Kalam, Hadi. "Political Violence Of Chatra League: A Chronology". Retrieved 6 May 2015. 
  2. ^ "Frequent violence plagues campus atmosphere". Retrieved 6 May 2015. 
  3. ^ Rangpur Correspondent, bdnews24.com. "Rangpur Medical College shut down indefinitely after BCL clash leaves 10 injured". Retrieved 6 May 2015. 
  4. ^ "Political Parties and Political Violence". Refworld. Research Directorate, Immigration and Refugee Board, Canada. May 1, 1994. Retrieved April 28, 2015. 
  5. ^ "Academic activities resume in IU". Daily Prothom Alo. June 27, 2015. Retrieved June 27, 2015.
